text: I swallow my words. This isn’t the time to press her.
“Let’s head back to the inn first.”
Lucia nods immediately, her fingertips turning pale from tension. “Okay… let’s go.”
Alicia doesn’t object. She only lets out a low “Mm.”
She slips the ring-shaped token inside her cloak, the movement practiced—like putting away a tool she’s used far too many times.
We leave Scrap Iron Alley. Fog and snow cling to our faces, and the streetlamps glow like crushed gold dust.
“Mentor… don’t walk so fast.”
Lucia hurries after her, tugging Alicia’s cloak higher, as if afraid the wind might slip through the seams and steal away the last of her warmth.
I lower my voice and ask Lucia, “Does she do this often… rushing in alone?”
Lucia bites her lip. After a second’s hesitation, she nods. “She thinks… the fewer people who know, the safer it is.”
“What about her? She doesn’t count as a person?”
Lucia’s eyes redden instantly. “She’s treated herself like a tool… for a long time.”
Up ahead, Alicia suddenly slows, as if she’s heard us. She doesn’t turn around—just grinds the snow beneath her boots into finer shards.
“Don’t talk about this out here.”
“You have to let people know what you’re doing.”
“Even if they know, it won’t help.”
Her tone is flat—flat like a rule that will never change.
The inn’s lights appear through the fog. When we push the door open, warmth rushes toward us.
Lucia quickly guides Alicia toward the fire. “Sit down. I’ll get some hot water—your hands are freezing.”
“No need.”
“There is.”
Lucia almost forces her into the chair before jogging into the back kitchen. Alicia stares into the firelight, her eyes empty for a brief moment—as if she’s nearly forgotten how to sit and rest.
I slide the bolt into place and turn to her. “You said ‘we’ll need it tomorrow.’ Are you planning to go again?”
She looks up, weariness edged with faint impatience. “Weren’t you the one who decided not to press?”
“I decided to bring you back first.”
She falls silent for a moment, as if weighing how much to reveal. “…I need to confirm something. That’s all.”
She shifts her gaze away, as though saying even one more word might tear a crack wider.
Lucia returns with hot water, placing it gently beside her. “Drink a little first. Don’t push yourself.”
That “Mm” is so soft it’s almost inaudible—but at least it isn’t a refusal.
